events.name: Diwali Festival in Bangalore
events.description: Diwali, also known as the Festival of Lights, is a major Hindu festival celebrated over five days. It symbolizes the victory of good over evil, light over darkness, and knowledge over ignorance. In Bangalore, Diwali is celebrated with great enthusiasm, featuring vibrant decorations, traditional sweets, lighting of lamps and diyas, fireworks, and family gatherings. Temples are decorated, and special prayers are offered to Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and prosperity.

schedule.activity: Day 1: Dhanteras. This day is dedicated to worshipping Lord Kubera, the god of wealth. People purchase new utensils, gold, or silver items. Homes are cleaned and decorated in preparation for Diwali. Markets will be bustling with shoppers.
highlights: Shopping for gold, silver, and utensils
Visit local markets like Commercial Street and Jayanagar 4th Block

schedule.activity: Day 2: Naraka Chaturdasi (Choti Diwali). Effigies of Narakasura are burnt at dawn to symbolize the destruction of evil. Special oil baths are taken, and new clothes are worn. Bangalore sees community celebrations and smaller firework displays.
highlights: Smaller firework displays in residential areas

schedule.activity: Day 3: Lakshmi Puja (Main Diwali Day). Morning prayers are offered in temples. Homes are decorated with diyas (oil lamps) and rangolis (colorful patterns). The main Lakshmi Puja takes place in the evening, followed by a feast and fireworks. Temples like ISKCON Bangalore and Gavi Gangadhareshwara Temple will have special pujas.
highlights: Decorating homes with diyas and rangolis
Spectacular fireworks display city-wide in the evening

schedule.activity: Day 4: Govardhan Puja. This day celebrates Lord Krishna's victory over Indra. Special vegetarian dishes are prepared and offered to the deities. Annakut (mountain of food) is prepared in some temples. In Bangalore, this day is often celebrated with community feasts and family gatherings.

Day 5: Bhai Dooj. This day celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters. Sisters pray for their brothers' well-being and perform a 'tika' ceremony. Brothers give gifts to their sisters. Many families travel to be together on this day. Expect increased traffic.

accessibility.wheelchair_accessible: Varies by location. Temples and public areas may have limited accessibility.

events.weather_considerations: October-November in Bangalore is generally pleasant with moderate temperatures (20-30°C/68-86°F). Light clothing is suitable. Evenings may be slightly cooler.
events.cultural_significance: Diwali celebrates the victory of good over evil and the return of Lord Rama to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile. It is a time for family, celebration, and spiritual reflection. The festival signifies new beginnings and the hope for prosperity in the coming year.

destination_context.local_transportation: Bangalore has a metro system (Namma Metro), buses, auto-rickshaws, and taxis. Ride-sharing apps like Ola and Uber are widely available. Traffic can be heavy, especially during the festival period.
destination_context.local_customs: Dress modestly when visiting temples. Remove shoes before entering temples and homes. Be mindful of noise levels, especially late at night. Bargaining is common in markets. Be respectful of religious traditions.

travel_recommendations.optimal_duration: 5 days recommended for a full Diwali experience
travel_recommendations.best_arrival_time: Arrive 1-2 days before Dhanteras (October 30 or earlier) to allow time to settle in and prepare for the festival.
travel_recommendations.accommodation_booking: Book accommodation at least 2-3 months in advance, as hotels fill up quickly during Diwali.
travel_tips: Be prepared for crowds, especially in markets and temples.
Carry sufficient cash, as some smaller shops may not accept cards.
Learn a few basic Kannada phrases (e.g., 'Namaskara' for hello).
Be aware of firework safety and follow local guidelines.
Stay hydrated and carry a water bottle.
